awd_titl_txt: Biogeochemical Processes along the Lower Amazon River Continuum
awd_abstract_narration:
This research addresses the movement of CO2 from rivers to the atmosphere, a phenomenon referred to as outgassing. Recently revised estimates of riverine outgassing suggest that it is a significant component of the global carbon cycle. But precisely how much outgassing occurs and what factors control the rates of outgassing remain poorly understood, especially in the lower, tidal reaches of large tropical rivers. Most measurements of outgassing are made far upstream of the ocean, and oceanography studies are restricted to zones that are offshore. This leaves a major knowledge gap, with little or no data available for extensive river reaches between upstream gauging station and offshore sites where oceanographic research vessels pick up the signal at sea. This project, with a focus on the Amazon River, will provide greater insights into how riverine carbon cycles function, and ultimately their influence on global cycles. The coupled models developed for the project will be available to policy makers for use in evaluating broader water resource issues of the changing Amazon basin.  The project will support the training of one graduate student and an undergraduate student recruited from an underrepresented minority. 
   
This research will use a combination of river boat expeditions, remote sensing, and modeling to test the hypothesis that dissolved CO2 levels remain above atmospheric saturation along the entire lower river and in the inner reaches of the plume. Under those conditions the Amazon River plume would act as a net source of CO2 to the atmosphere when freshwaters and low salinity waters are fully considered. The hypothesis that gaseous, dissolved, and particulate concentrations of carbon vary consistently with the tide will be evaluated through detailed measurements over tidal cycles. To obtain insights into the biological mechanisms regulating organic matter decomposition and energy production a combination of proteomic signatures of microbial metabolism and dissolved organic matter characterization by ultra-high-resolution mass spectrometry will be employed. Finally, a detailed hydrodynamic model, that includes biological processes and inputs from a basin hydrology model, will be used to provide synthesis across the project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. Rivers are significant to the global water and carbon cycles because they modulate carbon dynamics not only in their watersheds but also in their marine receiving waters. The Amazon River produces nearly 20% of the total global amount of freshwater to the oceans, draining an immense tropical rainforest. The amount of water carried by a large river reflects the overall water cycle of its drainage basin, including how it influences its shoreline and how the regional land structure modulates the water flow and ultimately timing and amount of water delivered to the ocean. Any changes in flow patterns would have major impacts on communities. Flowing water mobilizes vast amounts of CO2. Global estimates of CO2 flux from inland waters to the atmosphere (called outgassing) have increased significantly in the last decade as observations have become more widespread. However, data coverage is still sparse in remote locations especially in large tropical rivers, which contribute disproportionately to CO2 outgassing compared to temperate and high latitude systems. Of importance is not only the magnitude but the especially the dynamics producing the fluxes, as these are indicative of how the ecology of the river system is functioning. The first step in understanding carbon flow is to understand how water flows in the river (which is, of course, very important unto itself, for water resource purposes).  Detailed analysis of a 50-year record of Amazon flow at the last measuring station, by the city of Óbidos 800 km from the ocean and above the input of two major tributaries, shows that over the last 25 years that the differences between high flows and low flows is increasing. The droughts of 2023 and 2024 produced the lowest flows in at least 50 years. Using a technology called ADCP, the first measurements of flow at the lower-most Amazon, by the city of Macapá, were made. These measurements showed that the overall flow to the ocean increased by about 10% over the long-term Óbidos average of 176,000 m3/s. (Fun-fact: the total measured at Macapá in April 2017 of 326,000 m3/s is likely the highest flow ever directly measured). The measurements showed that over the course of a 12-hour tidal cycle that the river flow reversed, i.e. the river went backwards, when the tidal force was the greatest. The degree of current reversal and how long a parcel of water took to traverse from Óbidos to the ocean was strongly dependent on the season. “Balancing the checkbook” of how much water was where in the river showed that the section from Óbidos to the city of Almeirim was essentially constant, but that during rising river stage water was “lost” in the multi-channel labyrinth below Almeirim and was returned during the falling stages. With the water cycle more understood, the cycle of CO2 can be put into context. Continuous measurements of pCO2 (CO2 dissolved in water) and related parameters from Óbidos to the ocean showed that there was a consistent downstream decrease in pCO2 concentrations, with the highest values during rising and high-water stages, decreasing with falling water stages. pCO2 varied over tidal cycles, typically lower with greater water flow. The question is, what drives such changes, i.e., what are the dynamics producing these patterns? The level of pCO2 in a river sector is the product of however much entered from upstream balanced by how much is produced by respiration, consumed by photosynthesis (low, in these very turbid waters) and lost through outgassing. Outgassing itself is function of the pCO2 concentration in the water and how turbulent the water is. The downstream decrease in pCO2 is the product of outgassing slowly “winning” over respiration. What is not indicated is that inputs from the floodplains are a dominant source, unlike the conventional wisdom. Ongoing work is looking at how the biogeochemistry of the Amazon has evolved since the first modern measurements, starting in 1977.

Broader Impacts. This research has broader impacts in several arenas. The results contribute to understanding the dynamics of large rivers in the global water and carbon cycles. The project built intellectual capacity of young Brazilian scientists in the Amazon, Sao Paulo, and Rio de Janeiro.   The engagement of US and Brazilian students and Post-Docs working jointly is a model for how global geosciences can evolve.  Data and models will be available to contribute to analyzing the major resource issues facing the Amazon—not only longer-term climate change, but immediate land-use and development issues including agriculture and dams. Of relevance is the hydrodynamic model “SisBaHiA” (of the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro), used to analyze water flow properties in the project. This model would be of major use for navigation in the lower Amazon region.
